name: Stanwix Hall
description: Popular with local and state legislators, the notorious William “Boss” Tweed stayed in room 450 for many years when he ran Tammany Hall.
imageCredit: New York Public Library, CCO 1.0 Dedication

name: Delevan House
address: East side Broadway between Columbia & Steuben
description: While staying here, Teddy Roosevelt watched as bags of cash were doled out to legislators to pass or kill bills.

name: Kenmore Hotel
description: In 1888, New York World reporter Nellie Bly posed as a lobbyist and met with Mr. Edward R. Phelps, the “King of the Lobby”, in Room 96 at the Kenmore to prove that many New York legislators were bribable.

name: The State Capitol
description: Built between 1867 and 1899, the opulent State Capitol building has been the site of many corruption scandals.
imageCredit: Beyond My Ken, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons

name: The Dewitt Clinton Hotel
description: The DeWitt Clinton was known as the “Democrat’s Hotel” and was the center for backroom dealmaking.
imageCredit: Kheel Center, CC BY 2.0, via Wikimedia Commons

name: Ten Eyck Hotel
address: NW corner State & North Pearl St.
description: The Ten Eyck was the “Republican’s Hotel.”

name: “THREE-MEN-IN-A-ROOM” Room
description: “Three men in a room” was a term coined to describe  the secretive way deals were made in Albany. This involved  the Governor, the Assembly Speaker, and the Senate Majority Leader.

name: New York State Bank of Albany
address: NW corner of Broadway and State Street
description: In the early 1800’s, NY state banks had to be chartered by the legislature and lawmakers were quite content to be bribed with shares in those banks from awarding bank charters.
